user_question: How effectively is the company managing its pension plan investments and what is the composition of alternative investments in the portfolio as of December 31, 2024?
final_answer: The company's pension plan shows a balanced investment approach with alternative investments (carried at net asset value) representing 10.748% of total plan assets as of December 31, 2024. This indicates a moderate allocation to less liquid but potentially higher-yielding investments. The plan assets grew at a healthy 6.0% rate during 2024, suggesting effective investment management despite market volatility.

Effectiveness of pension‐asset management (2024 vs. 2023)

• Investment performance – Plan assets earned $1.91 billion in 2024.  Dividing that by the average asset base for the year (($13.38 b + $14.18 b)/2) gives a return of ≈13.9 %.  
• Funding – Assets finished the year at $14.18 b while projected benefit obligations (PBO) were $11.72 b, producing a surplus of $2.46 b and a funded ratio of ≈121 % (up from ≈105 % a year earlier).  
• Cash-flow efficiency – Employer contributions were modest ($111 m) compared with benefits paid ($810 m); the plan was therefore able to cover outflows largely with investment income, indicating strong liquidity and return generation.

Composition of alternative / non-traditional assets on 31 Dec 2024

Investment-funds-and-other category = $2.076 b, representing 14.6 % of total plan assets ($14.18 b).  Inside this sleeve:  
• Investments carried at net-asset-value (private equity, hedge/credit funds, real-estate partnerships, etc.) – $1.524 b (73.4 % of the alternative bucket; 10.8 % of total plan assets).  
• Publicly priced positions:  
 – Level 1 fair-value instruments – $385 m (18.5 % of alt bucket)  
 – Level 2 – $144 m (7.0 %)  
 – Level 3 – $23 m (1.1 %)

Broader asset mix: equity securities 68.8 %, fixed-maturity 12.3 %, cash 4.2 %, alternatives 14.6 %.

Taken together, Berkshire’s pension programme is being managed effectively: it generated a double-digit return, reduced reliance on company contributions, and improved the funded surplus to more than 20 % above liabilities, while maintaining a measured 15 % allocation to alternative investments that is dominated by NAV-priced partnership interests.
